comments.body: not sure on this one, but we can always add new checks in the future.

https://github.com/dominikh/go-tools/issues/656
It seems not correct in my opinion
I think it's also reasonable to focus on ensuring we fix the existing checks throughout the project and keep the tool up to date over enabling every single check immediately anyhow.

Agree.

But it may mislead new contributors to fix those that may not be a problem. We should check `-SA5011` again when upgrading static-check next time.  

To remove it now, we may add some guide information and comments in #92402.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +38,42 @@  "-S1*"    # Omit code simplifications for now.
  "-ST1*"   # Mostly stylistic, redundant w/ golint
  "-SA5011" # Possible nil pointer dereference
)
export IFS=','; checks="${CHECKS[*]}"; unset IFS

comments.body:
kube::util::read_array is a more widely compatible alternative to `mapfile -t`
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/66b0a0c17dff44e3ce1b2a2a95d8c1667e1277bf/hack/lib/util.sh#L729-L744

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +95,99 @@
export IFS=$'\n'
mapfile -t really_failing < <(sort -u <<<"${really_failing[*]}")
unset IFS
for pkg in "${failing_packages[@]}"; do

@@ -1,1 +57,61 @@
export IFS=$'\n'
# NOTE: when "go list -e ./..." is run within GOPATH, it turns the k8s.io/kubernetes
# as the prefix, however if we run it outside it returns the full path of the file
# with a leading underscore. We'll need to support both scenarios for all_packages.

comments.body: bikeshed: s/been checked/passed staticcheck/ ? they've been checked when they fail as well.

if [ ${#errors[@]} -eq 0 ]; then
  echo 'Congratulations!  All Go source files have been checked.'

comments.body: nit: we should probably suggest using this script instead of staticcheck directly, since it also controls for the staticcheck version?

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +122,126 @@    echo
    echo 'Please review the above warnings. You can test via:'
    echo "  staticcheck -checks \"${checks}\""
    echo 'If the above warnings do not make sense, you can exempt the line or file. See:'
    echo '  https://staticcheck.io/docs/#ignoring-problems'
